El negocio cuenta con muy buena acogida. Con esta actividad ella ayuda al sostenimiento económico de su familia.

Iris desea comprar un lote de mercadería para incrementar su stock y con la venta incrementar sus ingresos y por consiguiente mejorar su calidad de vida. Es por ello que ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo de 2000 nuevos soles de Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
Iris is 37 years old, single, and has two children.  She lives with her family in Chiclayo district, the capital of Lambayeque department.

Iris' business is buying and selling groceries and selling personal care products.  She has been in this business continually for more than five years.  She has her own premises which are located in the third sector of Moshoqueque market.  Her business is very popular.  Through her business, she helps her family financially.

Iris would like to buy a batch of merchandise to increase her stock.  Through the sales she makes, she will increase her income and, consequently, improve her quality of life.  For this reason, she has requested a loan for 2,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Gricerio

texts.es:
Gricerio tiene 48 años de edad, es conviviente y reside junto a su familia en el distrito de Olmos una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

La actividad que desarrolla  es el servicio de chofer en una empresa de transportes que se encuentra en  el distrito donde reside. Con esta actividad ha salido adelante junto a su familia.

Gricerio anhela aperturar un lugar donde pueda brindar servicio de lavado de motos en su domicilio, de esta manera incrementar sus ingresos para obtener una mejor calidad de vida.

Gricerio es responsable y muy trabajador, en la asociación trabaja se brindan apoyo cuando lo necesitan.
texts.en:
Gricerio is 48 years old.  He lives with his partner and family in Olmos district, an agricultural area with quite a lot of commercial activity, which is located in Lambayeque province, more than one and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo.

Gricerio works as a driver for a transport company in his district.  Through this work, he gets his family ahead in life.

Gricerio would like to open a place where he can provide a motorbike washing service on his property.  In this way, he will increase his income and be able to achieve a better quality of life.

Gricerio is responsible and very hard working.  In the association in which he works, they provide support for each other when they need it.

loans.use: to open a motorbike washing service

loans.name: Marlene Maclovia

texts.es:
La Señora. Marlene C. es socia del banco comunal Loma de la Cruz, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es patrimonio cultural de la humanidad desde 1999 gracias a su hermoso centro histórico, su gente mantienen su cultura y tradiciones, cuenta también con una gran variedad en su gastronomía.
 
Doña Marlene tiene 48 años de edad, es madre soltera de 6 hijos de 30, 26, 23, 21, 19 y 16 años de edad, sus tres primeros hijos son casados e independientes, su cuarto y quinto hijo trabajan y le ayudan economícamente, su ultimo hijo estudia en un colegio de la ciudad. No tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando.
 
La Señora. Marlene es comerciante, se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de la marca Yanbal y también ropa, todas sus ventas las hace bajo pedido y esta labor la realiza hace 20 años, trabaja de lunes a viernes sin un horario fijo y vende recorriendo la ciudad  a sus amigos y conocidos.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace nueve años y medio, el dinero de su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos y ropa para su selecta clientela.

Su mayor sueño es viajar por todo el mundo.
texts.en:
Marlene C. is a member of the 'Loma de la Cruz' community bank.  She lives in the city of Cuenca which was named a World Heritage Site in 1999 thanks to its beautiful historic center.  Its people maintain their culture and traditions and its cuisine is very wide ranging.

Marlene is 48 years old.  She is a single mother and has six children aged 30, 26, 23, 21, 19 and 16.  Her three eldest children are married and live independently.  Her fourth and fifth children work and help her financially, and her youngest is attending high school.  She does not own her own home but lives in a rental home.

Marlene is a saleswoman.  She sells Yanbal cosmetics and clothes.  She makes all her sales to order and has been in the business for 20 years.  She works from Monday to Friday but does not work fixed hours.  She makes her sales door to door to her friends and acquaintances.

Marlene has been a member of her community bank for nine and a half years.  She will invest the money from her new loan in buying cosmetics and clothes for her select customers.

Marlene's biggest dream is to travel around the world.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and clothes

loans.name: Ines De Jesús

texts.es:
La Señora. Inés G. es socia del banco comunal Loma de la Cruz, vive por la parroquia de Sinincay en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es patrimonio cultural de la humanidad desde 1999 gracias a su hermoso centro histórico, su gente mantienen su cultura y tradiciones, cuenta también con una gran variedad en su gastronomía.
 
Doña Inés se encuentra de 46 años, esta casada y tiene 4 hijos de 25, 21, 19 y 14 años de edad, su primera hija es casada e independiente, su segundo hijo estudia en la universidad, su tercer hijo trabaja para sus gastos personales y su ultima hija estudia en un colegio de la ciudad. Su esposo es de profesión sastre, con el trabajo en conjunto han logrado construir su casa propia.

La Señora. Inés labora junto con su esposo en su taller de sastrería, esta actividad la desempeña hace 12 años, realizan todo tipo de arreglos y costuras, laboran de lunes a viernes sin un horario fijo.

En el banco comunal se encuentra en su noveno crédito y a invirtiendo todos los créditos en su taller, este lo va a invertir en la compra de materia prima como telas, hilos, botones, cierres, etc.

Su mayor sueño es no tener deudas.
texts.en:
Inés G. is a member of the 'Loma de la Cruz' community bank.  She lives in Sinincay parish, in the city of Cuenca.  This city was named a World Heritage Site in 1999 thanks to its historic center.  Its people maintain their culture and traditions and its cuisine is very wide ranging.

Inés is 46 years old, married, and has four children aged 25, 21, 19 and 14.  Her eldest child (a daughter) is married and lives independently.  Her second child (a son) is studying at university.  Her third child (a son) works to cover his personal expenses and her youngest child (a daughter) attends high school.  Her husband is a tailor and, through their joint work, they have managed to build their own home.

Inés works together with her husband in his tailor's workshop.  She has been in this business for 12 years and together they do all kinds of repairs and sewing.  They work from Monday to Friday but don't work fixed hours.

Inés is receiving her ninth loan through her community bank.  She has invested all her previous loans in her workshop.  She will invest this loan in buying raw materials such as fabric, threads, buttons, fasteners, etc.

Inés' biggest dream is to not have any debts.

loans.use: to buy fabric, threads, buttons, fasteners, etc.

loans.name: Maria Silvia

texts.es:
La señora Maria Silvia E. y su esposo el señor Juan Vidaña, están solicitando una préstamo para pagar el tramite legan para la posesión de la propiedad y así  poderla  tener su propiedad a su nombre. Ya que es el patrimonio de sus hijos.
Doña Maria Silvia se dedica a tender a su familia y que no falte nada en la casa, ya que el señor Juan es quien trabaja en una compañía en el aria de ventas, este es el ingreso que tiene para la familia y con el cual una parte será para pagar el crédito.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria Silvia E. and her husband, Mr. Juan Vidaña, are requesting a loan to pay for the legal expenses for the ownership proceeding to become sole owners of their house, as this is the legacy they want to leave to their children.
Doña Maria Silvia is a housewife - taking care of her family and making sure there is nothing missing the house – while Juan works in the sales department of a company. His wage is the sole income of the family, and a part of it will be used to repay the loan.

loans.use: To pay for legal expenses for the ownership of her house.

loans.name: Blanca Alicia

texts.es:
La Señora Blanca C. es socia del banco comunal Loma de la Cruz, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es patrimonio cultural de la humanidad desde 1999 gracias a su hermoso centro histórico, su gente mantiene su cultura y tradiciones, cuenta también con una gran variedad en su gastronomía.
 
La Señora. Blanca tiene 65 años, es divorciada y tiene 4 hijos quienes son todos mayores de edad, tres son casados e independientes y su hijo soltero la ayuda en la atención de su tienda. No tiene casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.
Doña Blanca se dedica a la atención de su tienda la cual la tiene hace 9 años, trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace 2 años y los créditos le han beneficiado mucho en su tienda. El dinero de su nuevo crédito lo va ha invertir en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos para tener más variedad.
  
Su meta es  tener una tienda mucho más grande.
texts.en:
Ms. Blanca C. is a member of the Banco Comunal Loma de la Cruz (Hillock of the Cross Communal Bank). She lives in the city of Cuenca, an UNESCO World Heritage site since 1999 thanks to her beautiful historical city center. Its inhabitants preserve their culture and traditions, and it also offers a great gastronomical variety.

Blanca is 65 years old, she is divorces and she has 4 adult children. Three are married and economically independent, while her son, who is single, helps her running her shop. She lives in a rented house as she doesn’t have one of her own.

Doña Blanca engages in running her shop, which she opened 9 years ago, working form Sundays to Sundays form 6 am to 10 pm.

She has been a member of the communal bank for 2 years and her shop has benefited a lot from the loans. This new loan she is requesting will be used to buy rice, sugar, oils, detergents, sausages and other products in order to offer a wider variety of items.
She wishes to own a much bigger shop.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oils, detergents, sausages and other products.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Teresa, tiene 40 años de edad, está soltera y vive en casa de sus padres. Lleva en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta porque el banco es una gran ayuda ya que con los créditos personas como ella pueden ganarse la vida de una forma honesta.

Ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes en la casa de sus padres, allí además de vender productos  como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, también vende helados, sodas, y ciertas medicinas, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 22h00, los productos para surtir su negocio los compra en  Montecristi y Manta  pero la mayoría los recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que lleva en su negocio ya por 18 años.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad.
 
Su meta es tener un carro en el futuro.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Angels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

Here is where we meet Teresa, aged 40, who is single and lives in her parents’ house. She has been a member of the Communal Bank since the beginning, and she likes it because the bank is of great help to her as, thanks to the loans, people like her can earn a living in an honest way.

She runs a grocery store in her parents’ house where, on top of selling products such as rice, sugar, oils and detergents, she also sells ice-creams, fizzy drinks and some medicines. She works every day form 6 a to 10 pm, and to supply he shop she buys some of the products in Montecristi and in Manta, even though the majority are delivered to her shop. She told us she has been running her shop for 18 years.

She will use the loan she is requesting to purchase more supplies for her shop. She will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other basic necessities.

She wishes to own a car in the future.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other products to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Susana Mabel

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Susana, tiene 24 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen una hija de tres años. Su esposo es maestro en una escuela de Montecristi. Ella también es maestra de una escuela de la localidad.

Además de ser maestra también se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo y cosméticos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h30 hasta las 17h00, tanto en sus labores de maestra como de comerciante,  su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y bajo pedidos, además aprovecha en su escuela para venderles a sus compañeras y madres de familia que llegan hasta el establecimiento educativo, deja a crédito sus productos y cobra semanalmente. Su mercadería la compra en Portoviejo.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas, ropa de niños y cosméticos. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace cuatro ciclos  y le gusta porque les brinda la oportunidad de salir adelante con sus negocios.

Su sueño es ver que su hija tenga una muy buena educación.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Angels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

Here is where we meet Susana, aged 24, who is married and has a three-year-old daughter. Her husband is a school teacher in Montecristi, and she herself is a teacher in a school of her community.

On top of working as a teacher, she also engages in trade, selling clothes of every kind and cosmetics. She works every day form 6:30 am to 5 pm, both as a teacher and as a trader. She is a street vendor selling door to door and on request. She also takes advantage of working in a school to sell her products to her colleagues and to the mothers coming to the institute. She sells her products on credit than she collects weekly. She buys her products in Portoviejo.

She will use the loan she is requesting to buy more products such as trousers, blouses, T-shirts, children’s clothes and cosmetics. She has been a member of the Communal Bank for four cycles, and she likes it because it offers her the chance to progress with her activity.

She wishes to offer to her daughter the chance to have a very good education.

loans.use: To buy trousers, blouses, T-shirts, children's clothes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Jeremias

texts.en: Jeremias Q. is from the village of La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 31 years old. Jeremias is married and has two very young children. To make a living, Jeremias sells shoe products in the local community. Jeremias has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,200 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2011, Jeremias joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeremias is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new shoes to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jeremias from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Sonia Narcisa

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

La señora Sonia es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque los intereses son más bajos que en otras instituciones y además porque ha hecho muchas amigas en el grupo. Tiene 45 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene un  hijo de cuatro años de edad. Su esposo es obrero en el Municipio de Manta.

Ella es una muy buena ama de casa que también se dedica a preparar y vender bocadillos y comida rápida como: hamburguesas, hot dog, roscas, colas, aguas, entre otras cosas. Trabaja todos los días y nos cuenta que empezó este negocio con el primer crédito que obtuvo del banco comunal.

Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar sodas, aguas, pan, salchichas, carne y otros víveres para la preparación de los alimentos.

Su sueño es tener otro hijo.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Angels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

Sonia is a founder member of the Communal Bank, and she likes it because the interest rates are lower than those of other institutions and also because she has made many friends in the group. She is 45, she is married and she a 4-year-old child. Her husband is a laborer working in the town of Manta.

She is a very good housewife who also engages in preparing and selling sandwiches and fast foods such as hamburgers, hot dogs, doughnuts, colas and water among other things. She works every day and she told us she started this activity with the first loans she was granted from the Communal Bank.

She will use this loan to buy fizzy drinks, water, bread, sausages, meat and other ingredients to prepare her meals.

She dreams of having another child.

loans.use: To buy fizzy drinks, water, bread, sausages, meat and other ingredients for her meals.

loans.name: Elominada

texts.en:
Elominada A. is from the village of Lintugop, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 33 years old. Elominada is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Elominada owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing & selling nipa hut for sale to local businesses and community members. Elominada has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elominada joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elominada is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture nipa hut for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Elominada from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture nipa hut for sale

loans.name: Paula Dolores

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Paula, tiene 38 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijas de 8 y 3 años, la mayor estudia en escuela. Su esposo es chofer profesional.

Ella es profesora de una escuela fiscal en Montecristi y además de esto también se dedica a la venta de bisutería, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, vende anillos, collares, aretes, pulseras, etc. Trabaja todos los días en sus  ventas ya que también lleva sus productos a la escuela donde les vende a sus compañeras y a madres de familia que llegan hasta el centro educativo. Ella compra al por mayor a una distribuidora en Portoviejo, nos cuenta que lleva en este negocio ya por tres años y que le ha ido bien.

Este crédito es para comprar bisutería. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta por la seriedad tanto de la institución como de sus compañeras.

Su sueño es que sus hijas tengan un buen porvenir.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Angels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

Here we meet Paula, aged 38, who is married and has two daughters aged 8 and 3; the eldest goes to school. Her husband is a professional driver.

She is a teacher in a public school in Montecristi; on top of this she also sells costume jewelry. She is a street vendor selling door to door articles such as rings, necklaces, earrings, bracelets and so on. She runs both activities every day, as she brings her products to her school where she sells them to her colleagues and to the mothers coming there. She buys at wholesale price form a supplier in Portoviejo; she told us she has been engaging in this activity for three years and that things have been going well.

She will use this loan to purchase costume jewelry. She has been a member of the Communal Bank since the beginning, and she likes it because of the reliability both of the institution and of her teammates.

She hopes to be able to offer a better future to her daughters.

loans.use: To buy costume jewelry such as bracelets, necklaces and earrings.

loans.name: María Elizabeth

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora María, tiene 21 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen un bebé de 10 meses. Su esposo es maestro en aluminio y vidrio. Este año ella va a empezar a estudiar en un instituto superior para ser licenciada en educación.

Ella tiene una tienda de víveres de consumo en su casa en la cual vende todo tipo de productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. En ella  trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, además de estos productos también vende productos Avon (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas) los mismo que vende en su local y a veces recorre la ciudad. Nos cuenta que lleva tres años con su tienda y que empezó con el primer crédito que recibió de la institución.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta por el hecho de que con su primer crédito puso su negocio.
 
Su meta es algún dia tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Agels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

This place is where we meet Maria, aged 21, who is married and has a 10-months-old child. Her husband is a craftsman working with aluminum and glass. Later this year, she will start attending classes in an institute to get a diploma in education.

She has set a general store in her house where she sells every kind of product such as rice, sugar, oils, detergents and so on. She works there every day form 6 am to 8 pm, even until later sometimes. On top of the aforementioned products she also ells Avon products (beauty items, cosmetics, perfumes and accessories for women): she sells them in her shop and sometimes she also sells them door to door. She told us she has been running her shop for three years and that she started thanks to the first loan she received from the institution.

She will use the amount of this loan to supply her shop by buying rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other basic necessities. She has been a member of the Communal Bank since the beginning, and she likes it because thanks to the first loan she was able to open her shop.

She wishes to have a house of her own someday.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents and other basic necessities to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Dulamjav

texts.en:
Dulamjav is a 47-year-old woman who lives with her husband and two daughters in an apartment in Suhbaatar district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is a manager in a private company with monthly salary of 350,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). Her older daughter, Gunbileg, goes to a college and the younger one attends a local secondary school. 

Dulamjav manages a construction-goods trading business at a rented stall at a Bolor trading center. She started her business in 2002. Even though she graduated as a veterinarian in 1985, she never worked as a vet. She had to become businesswoman in order to earn money and provide better living conditions for her family. 

She is a diligent lady who says, "I want to expand my business in the future." She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more construction goods for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more construction goods

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn M. is from the city of Cebedo Extension, Ozamiz City. She is 39 years old. Evelyn is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Evelyn operates a transportation service. The main source of income for the business comes from operating motor-transport services. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2011, Evelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase motor accessories and to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase motor accessories and to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Baatarhuu

texts.en: Baatarhuu is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife is an inspector in a government agency. His older daughter named Munhbayasgalan is a student, while his son named Munh-Erdene is a pupil. Baatarhuu manages a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2009. At first he used to ride a cheap Korean car called Excel. Recently his business was quite successful and that allowed him to buy a new car. Now he drives a Japanese car which he bought in 2011 with 4.8 million Mongolian tugriks (MNT). Before his taxi-service business, he used to work as a constructor. He is a hardworking man with lots of good personality. He is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 MNT to buy a new car in order to provide more comfortable service for his customers.

loans.use: to buy a new car

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora María, tiene 49 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 18, 17 y de 15 años  de edad, los tres están en colegio. Su esposo es artesano. Lleva en el Banco Comunal cuatro ciclos y le gusta porque con los créditos puede financiar su negocio.

Tiene un local en la Ciudad Alfaro (lugar de bastante acogida turística), en ese lugar tiene un local en el cual vende artesanías, pulseras, sombreros, entre otras cosas. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 18h00, sus hijos le ayudan en su negocio, sus productos los compra a artesanos en Montecristi, lleva 14 años que se dedica a este negocio y con su local desde que se realizo la asamblea en Ciudad Alfaro.

Este crédito es para comprar más artesanías e incrementar su negocio.
 
Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su negocio y lograr darles la mejor educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Los Tres Ángeles (The Three Angels Communal Bank) meets every fortnight in the Montecristi Canton, a place renowned for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its arts and crafts, celebrated both at national and international level. It is also the homeland of the famous Toquilla straw hats.

Here is where we meet María, aged 39, who is married and has three children aged 18, 17 and 15; all of her children go to school. Her husband is a craftsman. She has been a member of the Communal Bank for four cycles, and she likes it because, thanks to the loans, she is able to fund her shop. 

She has a room in Ciudad Alfaro (a place with a fare tourist activity) where she sells crafts, bracelets and hats among other things. She works every day from 8 am to 6 pm, and her children help her in the shop. She buys her products form craftsmen in Montecristi, and she has been engaging in this activity for 14 years, while she has been owning the room since the bank assembled in Ciudad Alfaro.

She will use the amount of this loan to buy more crafts and so increase her sales volume.

She wishes to continue her activity and to be able to pay for the best education for her children.

loans.use: To buy crafts products to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Sugirmaa

texts.en:
Sugirmaa, 40, is married and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Suhbaatar district, Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her son, age 20, attends a college and her daughter, age 13, goes to a local secondary school. 

She operates a construction-goods trading business with the help of her husband at a rented stall at a Construction Trading Center, one of the biggest markets. She started her business in 2008 after working as a cook for seven years. Back then, she was paid very low compared with her earnings she receives now. 

She is an honest woman who attributes her business success to her good accounting skills. She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase more inventory to sell in the coming warm seasons when sales get higher.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Jenry

texts.en:
Jenry L. is from the Village of Poblacion, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 31 years old and married. To make a living, Jenry owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling mobile phone cards in the local community. Jenry has been in this business for over 4 years, and earns approximately 11200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jenry joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation, and his ability to engage in business activities. Jenry successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC. The previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory to sell. Jenry is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP. The loan will be used to purchase new cell phone accessories and gadgets, and to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jenry from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions for his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new cell phone accessories and gadgets

loans.name: Hayanhyarvaa

texts.en:
Hayanhyarvaa is a 47-year-old man who lives with his wife and two children in their own house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife and daughter, age 23, are unemployed while his son, age 24, helps with his business. He manages a public-transportation service in Ulaanbaatar city. He started his business in 1999 with only one minibus. With 12 years of business experience, he has been able to build a good relationship both with his partners and customers. Now he owns two minibuses and earns 70,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) daily. He also pays 10,000 MNT of salary to his conductors per day and his net monthly profit is 400,000-500,000 MNT. 

Since beginning his business operation, his living conditions have been rising tentatively. He is happy to feel improvements both in his life and in his career. He is a very delightful and cheerful person who was thankful with our bank service. He is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to repair his house in order to make his life much better.

loans.use: to repair his house

loans.name: Togtbayar

texts.en: Togtbayar is a 43-year-old woman who lives with her husband and only daughter in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in Hovd province, Mongolia. Her husband is a welder who works at home. Her only child, who is 6 years old, attends kindergarten. She owns a clothing-trading business in her town. She started her business in 2000 at a rented container in a local market. Through her hard work, she managed to buy her container in 2008 and expanded her business. Before that, she worked as a salesperson at someone else's stall and gained much experience. Now she sells all types of clothing such as hats, skirts, T-shirts and socks at her container. She is an honest woman who says, "I want to have my own house in (the) near future." She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase more inventory for her clothing business.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory for her clothing business

loans.name: Tsetsgee

texts.en:
Tsetsgee is a 58-year-old woman who lives with her two daughters and her grandchildren in their own house in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her grandchildren stay home and her two daughters, age 25 and 30, help with the family business. 

She operates a knitwear business in her town. She started her business in 2005 at her home. She knits collections of clothes such as skirts, hats and dresses using threads made of wool. She purchases her threads from Goyo and Gobi Company, which are the biggest knitwear manufacturing companies in Mongolia. Now she produces two to three pieces of products per day and her monthly net profit is 500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). 

Her older daughter worked as a knitter at Goyo Company for 10 years. So Tsetsgee never had worries about her business operation. She has a very experienced and trusted partner. She is a diligent and polite woman who is planning to have her own factory in the future. She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase a wide variety of threads.

loans.use: to purchase a wide variety of threads

loans.name: Vergenia

texts.en:
Vergenia Y. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Vergenia is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, cultivating fruit trees and harvesting their fruit to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $940 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Vergenia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from GDMPC. 

Vergenia is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and to pay for the labor cost of farm maintenance. This will be her 19th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and to pay for the labor cost of farm maintenance.

loans.name: Nachinbaatar

texts.en:
Nachinbaatar is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in his brother's backyard in the Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son, age 6, attends kindergarten while his younger daughter, who is only 2 months old, stays home. 

He operates a newspaper and book selling business out of a rented stall at Narantuul market, one of the crowded and busiest markets in Ulaanbaatar city. His wife helps with the family business. He has been managing his business for six years and gained much experience. Besides newspapers, he sells books, magazines and stationery as well. However, his business wasn't successful last year, so he wants to expand the variety of his products in order to attract more people of different ages.

He is a very delightful person who has good communication skills. He is planning to expand his business in the near future. He says, "I like to work hard in order to help my business flourish, even when the sales are very slow." He is requesting a loan of 800,000 MNT to purchase more books and journals for his business. In addition, he wants to purchase computer parts in order to manage a small computer service business.

loans.use: to purchase more books and journals

loans.name: Zeinegul's Group

texts.en:
Zeinegul K. is the leader of this group.  She is 35 years old and married to a chief accountant. Together with her husband she is bringing up four daughters and a son. Three older daughters are at school and the other children are not yet old enough. 

In order to earn money Zeinegul sells Oriflame cosmetics.  She started this activity a year ago with the initial investment of 3,000 KGS and now she earns about 2,000 KGS ($43) per month. With money received from the loan she will purchase more cosmetics to sell.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Muhabbat's Group

texts.en:
Muhabbat B. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Nookat – a nice village in the Osh region.  She is 39 and married. Her husband went to work in Russia to make money. Muhabbat takes care of four children: two boys and two girls. The sons and the first daughter are at school, but the second daughter is not yet, because she is preschool age (under seven). 

In order to earn additional money to meet the family's needs, Muhabbat sells stationery near the school, and also with the help of her sons she breeds livestock animals. With money received from the loan Muhabbat wants to purchase more sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more sheep for breeding

loans.name: Nurila's Group

texts.en:
Nurila J. is the leader of this group. She is 56 years old and married to a shepherd.  Together with her husband, she brings up three children. The older son is unemployed and the others study at school. 

In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Nurila breeds livestock animals. She resells some livestock at a higher price after fattening. In this way she earns about $64 per month. With money received from the loan, Nurila will purchase more goats for breeding. In the near future she wants to start breeding poultry.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more goats

loans.name: Maral's Group

texts.en:
Maral K., 46, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur – a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Her husband works as a foreman, and together they have raised two sons and a daughter. The sons study at university and the daughter is at school. 

The family breeds livestock animals for making additional money. They have three cows and fifteen sheep. With money received from the loan, Maral wants to increase the number of livestock and purchase five more sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase five more sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell, and to build a new room in his house.

loans.name: Jazgul's Group

texts.en:
Jazgul C. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 28 and married to a constructor. Together with her husband, she is bringing up a daughter and two sons. The first son is at school and the other children are not yet, because they are preschool age (under seven). 

Four years ago, with the initial investment of 1,500 KGS, Jazgul started to breed goats. Reselling goats after being fattened, she makes about an additional $85 per month. With money received from the loan, she will purchase more goats for breeding. In the future, Jazgul dreams to build a big house for the family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more goats

loans.name: Baatar

texts.en:
Baatar is a 34-year-old man who lives with his wife and three children in the Suhbaatar province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the Mongolian traditional housing tent, in someone's backyard. His two older children attend the local secondary school, while his wife stays home taking care of their infant.

He manages a meat trading business between Baruun-Urt sum and Ulaanbaatar city. He started his business in 2009, partnering with his brother. In 2010, he began conducting his business by himself, and is planning to expand his business in the future. He is an experienced businessman who says, "I want to buy a plot of land in order to build a house for my family." 

Baatar is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more sheep and goats in order to increase his business sales.

loans.use: to purchase more sheep and goats

loans.name: Sman

texts.en:
Sman N. operates her own small business, braiding fish nets and traps at home for earning a profit. She has two kids who assist her in making these tools. She either sells her items in bulk to middlemen or retails to people who use the tools to fish along the river. 

She doesn’t have a life partner because she was divorced from her husband many years ago. She is blessed six children. One is already married and lives independently, and the remaining children are single. Four of her children are working at different occupations. 

She is concerned because she faces a problem with her living conditions because her house is too old, and it has not been repaired for long time. Sman N. would like to ask for loan in order to repair her old house.

loans.use: to repair her old house

loans.name: Mirgul's Group

texts.en:
Mirgul U. is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married. Her husband earns money by taking orders and making furniture. Together they are bringing up three daughters and a son. The daughters are at school and the son is not yet. He is preschool age (under seven). 

Mirgul likes to spend time with children, so she works in a kindergarten and she loves her job. A year ago, her husband’s parents gave them a cow as a present. And since that moment the family has been breeding cattle. 

With money received from the loan, Mirgul would purchase more farm animals for breeding. In the future, she wants to build a shed, increase the number of cattle and make money to purchase a vehicle for the family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals

loans.name: Syrgabu's Group

texts.en:
Syrgabu T. is the leader of this group. She is 55 and married. Together with her husband, who works at school, she has raised seven children: six sons and a daughter. Most of the sons are married and live separately with their families. The daughter, 18, studies in Bishkek. 

Syrgabu is engaged in cattle breeding. She started this activity 22 years ago and her business runs well. She earns 2,000 KGS per month by reselling farm animals. With money received from the loan she would purchase livestock for breeding. In the near future Syrgabu plans to start building a new big shed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Mas

texts.en:
Mas T. is a 35-year-old married woman who has been selling fresh fish in the busy market for many years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier or at the river, which is full of fishermen. 

Mas T. is a single mother. She was married, but she has been divorced from her husband for years. 

Mas T. has an old motorbike that she always uses to transport her fresh fish to sell, but now it is broken. She will use her loan to buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle to transport her fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a bigger truck

loans.name: Asel's Group

texts.en:
Asel I., 21, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tup and is studying to be a financial specialist. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 8,000 KGS, Asel started to breed cattle. Now she sells 9 to 10 liters of milk every day and earns an additional 3,000 KGS per month. 

With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase cattle to resell at a higher price after fattening. 

In the near future she wants to graduate her university successfully. 
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara K. is the leader of this group. She is 29 and married to a security guard. Together with her husband she is bringing up two sons and a daughter. The daughter studies at school and the sons are preschool age (under seven). 

Gulnara works as a nurse in the hospital. She also sells milk every day to make additional money, and she earns an additional 2,000 KGS per month. 

She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase 800kg of potato seeds. In the near future Gulnara plans to sow wheat and potatoes, and she wants to get a good harvest.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional fish for selling

loans.name: Akylkan's Group

texts.en:
Akylkan K., 57, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tup and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised four daughters and two sons; most of whom are married and employed. 

In 1996, when the collective farms broke up, Akylkan got a piece of land for farming. Since that moment she has been cultivating agricultural products. In order to earn money she sells some part of the harvest. In this way she earns 2,000 KGS per month. 

With money received from the loan, Akylkan would purchase 250 kg of wheat seeds. 

In the near future she wants to start repairing the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.use: to purchase wheat seeds

loans.name: Hugo Mar

texts.es: Hugo tiene 71 años de edad y es soltero. Vive en casa propia con su hermano en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo. Durante toda su vida, Hugo se ha dedicado a la crianza y venta de ganado mayor y menor como los vacunos, caprinos y ovinos. Esta actividad es su principal fuente de ingresos para su sustento diario. Actualmente, su casa se encuentra en un estado deteriorado. Desea usar su crédito para hacer unos arreglos en su hogar lo que mejorará su condición de vida. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 700 nuevos soles. Con este préstamo, Hugo no tendrá que recurrir a prestamistas informales los cuales le cobrarían tasas altísimas. Edpyme le ofrece su crédito a una tasa de interés más baja que otras entidades bancarias y los prestamistas informales. Eso le permitirá a Hugo trabajar tranquilo sin perjudicar su liquidez diario. Hugo posee muy buenas referencias personales y laborales de su comunidad rural.  Es muy responsable y cumple con sus obligaciones de manera puntual.
texts.en: Hugo is 71 years old and he is single. He lives in his own house with his brother in the Olmos district, a rural area with a good commercial activity located in the Lambayeque province and at more than an hour and a half form the city of Chiclayo. For all of his life, Hugo has engaged in breeding and selling livestock such as cattle, goats and sheep. This activity is his main source of income for his everyday necessities. As his house is currently in a dilapidated state, he wishes to use his credit to make some repairs in his house, thus improving his living conditions. For this reason he has thought it convenient to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 700 PEN. Thanks to this loan, Hugo will not have to turn to informal loan sharks that would ask for very high interest rates. Edpyme grants him his loan at a lower interest rate than other banks and loan sharks. This will enable Hugo to work comfortably without risking his daily liquidity. Hugo has received very good personal and professional references from his rural community. He is very responsible and he promptly complies with his obligations.

loans.use: To make some repairs to his house.

loans.name: Dinar's Group

texts.en:
Dinar C., 41, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of the village of Tyup in the northern part of the country. 

Dinar and her husband, who is a farmer, have six children. She has owned a dairy business for 15 years now and it yields five to six liters of milk per day, which she sells for 15 KGS per liter. The business was started in 1995 and brings 2,000 KGS of monthly income nowadays. 

The purpose of the loan is to purchase three sheep for broadening the family household. 
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Mairamkan's Group

texts.en:
Mairamkan R., 46, is the leader of this group. She resides in the village of Tyup and has three children. 

Mairamkan and her husband both teach in high school and are also engaged in farming. The business was started 16 years ago during the privatization of land. Currently, its monthly revenue reaches 5,000 KGS. 

Mairamkan applied for this loan in order to buy 300 kg of wheat seeds and 500 kg of potato seeds. She hopes to successfully finish the spring field work. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. loans.use: to purchase potato seeds

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en: Ganbold G. is 47 years old, married, and has one child who attends college. They live in a rented apartment in Narantuul area, Ulaanbaatar, the capital Mongolia. His wife is disabled and must stay home all day. Ganbold manages a public transportation service business in Ulaanbaatar city. He started his business in 2000. Since then he has worked hard to stabilize and expand his business. His daily earning is 60,000 MNT and he pays 12,500 MNT to his conductors. He is one of the reliable and safe drivers amongst his colleagues. He is an honest man who says, "I want to have my own apartment in the near future." He is requesting a loan for 2,000,000 MNT  to pay his daughter's college tuition fees.

loans.use: To pay college tuition fees

loans.name: Tinh's Group

texts.en:
Tinh T. N., a 30-year-old mother of two children who are in elementary school, has run a grocery shop since receiving her first loan in 2003. Her business has developed well and now earns a profit of 4,000,000 per month, money that helps Tinh meet her family's requirements and buy some essential equipment for her house. Participating in our credit program, she has a good repayment record that qualifies her for increasingly larger loans. Tinh now wants to borrow 8,502,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy more products for her shop.

Loc T. D., a 43-year-old mother of two children, is currently raising five pigs for meat. She is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy food for them.

Dao T. N., 39, is raising 300 chickens for their eggs and needs a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy food for them.

Phien T. N., 45, is raising six pigs for meat and needs a loan of 5.014.000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy food for them.

Vi T. N., a 33-year-old chicken breeder, wants to borrow 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy food for them.

Chung T. T. N., a 35-year-old mother of three children, is a carpenter requesting a loan of 5,014,000 Vietnamese dong to buy a new tool set.

loans.use: to buy more products for the shop

loans.name: Chynar's Group

texts.en:
Chynar S., 40, leads this group. She resides in Tokmok and works as a cook, while her husband is an assistant machine operator in a local plant. After work, Chynar finds the time and enthusiasm to cope with the household chores, including taking care of livestock that the family has owned for three years. Since then, the livestock number has grown rapidly and Chynar plans to add more by using the loan from Kiva. The monthly income of 2000 soms and future profits will help her repay the loan in a timely fashion.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly L., 61, a low-income person living in the commune of Phnom Penh, sells fresh fish in her community to earn a living. Everyday in the late morning, Ly  buys fish in bulk from local fishermen and then hurries to the market where she retails them. Her husband, a merchandise-seller in the provinces, wishes to enlarge his business by purchasing more merchandise to sell, and so Ly is requesting a loan for that purpose.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise for her husband to continue selling.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira A., 41, is the leader of this group. She resides in the town of Tokmok and sells fruits and vegetables in a local open air market. She’s happy for having constant demand from the local food processing firms. The business was started together with her husband eight years ago with an initial capital of 10,000 KGS. 

Elmira hopes to use the loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables wholesale and increase sales. 
  
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam K., age 27, resides in the province of Siem Reap. She is married to Sophorn, 24, a policeman as well as a motor taxi driver, and they have one child who is still young. 

Sam K. sews clothes as a daily routine. She provides her service to her neighbors, sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. She runs her business very well and many customers recognize the good service she provides. 

Sam K. will use her loan to purchase cloth and more tailoring tools for providing her sewing service.

loans.use: to purchase some cloth and more tailoring tools

loans.name: Shamim Akhter's Group

texts.en:
Shamim Akhter is very helpful by nature. She supports her family financially by running a grocery store adjacent to her home. Through her store, she sells different grocery items such as cooking oil, spices, sugar, etc. at reasonable rates. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her business. Through the loan, she will be able to purchase groceries in bulk quantity which will help her fulfill the needs of customers and earn better profits. 

Shamim is confident that an investment will play an important role in expanding her business. She is also a very good mother. She takes care of her 13-year-old daughter and also performs her household duties efficiently.  She lives with her family in the area of Al-Fateh town which is a small residential area of Chichwatni. Chichawatni is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shamim Akhter.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong T. T.  N. is 37 years old and has two children. 

She is managing a shop that sells aquatic products such as snails, crabs and fish. Her business has been opened for six years since she received a loan in 2005. Her business is quiet good. It provides a profit of 3,000,000 VND that is very useful to her in managing her family life. 

She is an enthusiastic client of our program and has helped us to increase the number of  new clients in her village. 

This year, she wants to have a loan of 8,938,000 VND to purchase an oxygen pumping machine for the fish.

loans.use: to purchase an oxygen pumping machine for fish

loans.name: Kisanga Group

texts.en:
Hamimu M. is in his mid forties, married, and has five children all of whom attend school. He has a fruit and vegetable business where he works from 6.00 am to 8.00 pm daily. He is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be Hamimu's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He is requesting a loan to increase his capital in order to buy more fruits and vegetables.  His dream is to improve his children's education and also have a food shop business.

Hamimu will share this loan with his loan group "Kisanga," which has 18 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Hamimu is in the middle, front row wearing a blue shirt.

loans.use: To increase on the capital in order to buy more fruits and vegetables.
